docs.lead_paragraph: Eliot Spitzer stands so tall this election season that some New Yorkers might be excused for thinking he is governor already. (The deeply receding profile of Gov. George Pataki makes that a lot easier.) But there are two elections between the attorney general and the governor's office, the first being the Democratic primary on Sept. 12. Democratic voters are being asked to choose between Mr. Spitzer and the Nassau county executive, Thomas Suozzi, for a nominee for governor. With little money or statewide notice, Mr. Suozzi is running his hard-fought campaign against enormous odds, and this is a lopsided contest. Nevertheless, this is one of those rare races in which the electorate cannot lose. Both men have excellent records. Mr. Suozzi has made impressive strides turning around a troubled Nassau County government. Mr. Spitzer has so revitalized the attorney general's office in Albany that he has become a national hero.
docs.abstract: Editorial endorses Attorney General Eliot Spitzer in New York State's Democratic gubernatorial primary

docs.lead_paragraph: The State of New Jersey says it will help you save money on prescription drugs. How? By using the Internet.

headline.main: Prescription Shopping Online on Its Way

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov Jon Corzine signs into law bill, aimed at people without insurance or whose coverage is incomplete, that would allow customers to compare prices for prescription drugs on Internet; officials hope to have site running by 2007 (S)
docs.snippet: The State of New Jersey says it will help you save money on prescription drugs.      How? By using the Internet.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Smart Care Via a Mouse, but What Will It Cost?'' (Aug. 20), which described the new world of computerized patient records: It sounds wonderful: speedy transmittal of data, better control of prescription information and so on. Unfortunately, wrong information can be sent as quickly as correct information. If you've ever tried to correct credit card bill, insurance or bank statement, you know how difficult it is to reach the right person who has the authority to make corrections. How much worse could it be when your health is at stake? And what if you don't even realize that a mistake has been made?

headline.main: When Patients' Records Move to the Computer

docs.abstract: Margaret Eisner, vascular surgeon Jeffrey L Kaufman and TriCounty Family Medicine medical director Geoffrey Wittig letters on August 20 article on computerizing patient records; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: The political debate over Plan B may have helped raise the profile of its maker, Barr Pharmaceuticals, but over-the-counter sales will barely register on its balance sheet.
